fields.value: Replication data for: Multidimensional Responsiveness: The Determinants of Legislators' Representational Priorities

dsDescriptionValue.value: American politics scholars typically conceptualize representation narrowly as mass-elite policy responsiveness, with many studies identifying factors that hinder that relationship. These findings contrast with the high reelection rates in American legislatures. I show that policy is only one of several dimensions through which legislators provide representation. I unify policy, service, allocation, and descriptive representation in a model of legislators’ priorities and then test it with survey experiments administered to 1,175 state legislators. I posit that legislators systematically emphasize different dimensions to further the goal of reelection. Results show that legislative institutions, district demand, and individual traits structure legislators’ strategic representational priorities.

publicationCitation.value: Harden, Jeffrey J. 2013. "Multidimensional Responsiveness: The Determinants of Legislators' Representational Priorities." Forthcoming, Legislative Studies Quarterly

value: Only the online appendix is publicly available. The replication data is withheld to protect survey respondent anonymity. Please contact Jeff Harden for replication information.
